Summary 0:
Collective investment undertakings (AIFs) and UCITS Collective investment undertakings (AIFs) and UCITS SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1156 on facilitating cross-border distribution of collective investment undertakings and amending Regulations (EU) No 345/2013, (EU) No 346/2013 and (EU) No 1286/2014 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the cross-border distribution of AIFs and UCITS by establishing uniform rules on the publication of national rules concerning marketing requirements for collective investment undertakings and on marketing communications addressed to investors, as well as common principles concerning fees and charges levied on managers of collective investment undertakings in relation to their cross-border activities. It also provides for the establishment of a central database on the cross-border marketing of collective investment undertakings. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to: alternative investment funds (AIFs) and UCITS management companies, including any UCITS which has not designated a UCITS management company; European venture capital funds (EuVECA) and European social entrepreneurship funds (EuSEF); European long-term investment funds (ELTIF) and undertakings for collective investment in transferable securities (UCITS) within the meaning of Directive 2009/65/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council. The regulation also provides for the establishment of a central database on the cross-border marketing of collective investment undertakings. The regulation also provides for the establishment of a central database on the cross-border marketing of collective investment undertakings. The regulation also provides for the establishment of a central database on the cross-border marketing of collective investment undertakings. The regulation also provides for the establishment of a central database on the cross-border marketing of collective investment undertakings. The regulation also provides for the establishment of a central database on the cross-border marketing of collective investment undertakings. The regulation also provides for the establishment of a central database on the cross-border marketing of collective investment undertakings. The regulation also provides for the establishment of a central database on the cross-border marketing of collective investment undertakings. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 August 2019. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Alternative investment funds (European Commission). KEY TERMS Alternative investment funds: AIFs that are authorised in accordance with Directive 2011/61/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council. Market surveillance and compliance of products Market surveillance and compliance of products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 on market surveillance and compliance of products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the functioning of the internal market by strengthening the market surveillance of products covered by EU harmonisation legislation. It lays down rules and procedures for economic operators regarding products subject to certain EU harmonisation legislation and establishes a framework for cooperation with economic operators. It also provides a framework for controls on products entering the EU market. KEY POINTS The regulation lays down rules and procedures for economic operators regarding products subject to certain EU harmonisation legislation and establishes a framework for cooperation with economic operators. It also provides a framework for controls on products entering the EU market. The regulation also provides a framework for controls on products entering the EU market. The regulation also provides a framework for cooperation with economic operators regarding actions which could eliminate or mitigate risks that are presented by products made available on the market by those operators. The regulation also provides for joint activities to promote compliance, identifying non-compliance, raising awareness and providing guidance in relation to the EU harmonisation legislation with respect to specific categories of products, in particular categories of products that are often found to present a serious risk, including products offered for sale online. The regulation also provides for a single information and communication system for market surveillance, which allows users to access information about the product requirements and rights, obligations and rules derived from the EU harmonisation legislation. The regulation also provides for a single liaison office to assist in the cooperation between market surveillance authorities in different EU countries. The regulation also provides for a single information and communication system for market surveillance, which allows users to access information about the product requirements and rights, obligations and rules derived from the EU harmonisation legislation. The regulation also provides for a single information and communication system for market surveillance, which allows users to access information about the product requirements and rights, obligations and rules derived from the EU harmonisation legislation. Online services for broadcasting organisations Online services for broadcasting organisations SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/789 — rules on the exercise of copyright and related rights applicable to certain online transmissions of broadcasting organisations and retransmissions of television and radio programmes WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to facilitate cross-border access to a greater number of television and radio programmes by facilitating the licensing of copyright and related rights in works and other protected subject matter contained in broadcasts of certain types of television and radio programmes. It also lays down rules for the transmission of television and radio programmes through the process of direct injection. KEY POINTS The directive covers ancillary online services offered by a broadcasting organisation, which have a clear and subordinate relationship with the broadcasting organisation’s broadcasts. These services include services that give access to television and radio programmes in a strictly linear manner, simultaneously to the broadcast, and services that give access, within a defined time period after the broadcast, to television and radio programmes which have been previously broadcast by the broadcasting organisation, so-called catch-up services. The country of origin principle does not apply to any subsequent communication to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, or to any subsequent making available to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, in such a way that members of the public may access them from a place and at a time individually chosen by them, or to any subsequent reproduction of the works or other protected subject matter which are contained in the ancillary online service. Summary 3:
EU top-level domain name (TLD) EU top-level domain name (TLD) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/517 on the implementation and functioning of the.eu top-level domain name WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to support the digital single market, build an online European identity and encourage cross-border online activities. It lays down the conditions for its implementation, including the designation and characteristics of the registry. KEY POINTS The regulation lays down the eligibility criteria for the registration of one or more domain names under the.eu TLD. The registration of one or more domain names is available to eligible parties, subject to availability. The registry may revoke a domain name at its own initiative, without submitting the dispute to an ADR or judicial procedure, on the following grounds: there are outstanding unpaid debts owed to the registry; the non-fulfilment by the domain name holder of the eligibility criteria; the breach by the domain name holder of the requirements for registration requests. The registry may revoke a domain name at its own initiative, without submitting the dispute to an ADR or judicial procedure, on the following grounds: there are outstanding unpaid debts owed to the registry; the non-fulfilment by the domain name holder of the eligibility criteria; the breach by the domain name holder of the requirements for registration requests. The registry may revoke a domain name at its own initiative, without submitting the dispute to an ADR or judicial procedure, on the following grounds: there are outstanding unpaid debts owed to the registry; the non-fulfilment by the domain name holder of the eligibility criteria; the breach by the domain name holder of the requirements for registration requests. The registry may reserve or register a number of domain names considered necessary for its operational functions under the contract referred to in Article 8(4). The Commission may instruct the registry to reserve or register a domain name directly under the.eu TLD for use by the Union institutions and bodies. The registry may impose fees. The regulation sets out the rules, policies and procedures for the provision of services by the registry and the conditions according to which the Commission is to supervise the organisation, administration and management of the.eu TLD by the registry. The regulation also establishes the legal and general policy framework within which the designated registry is to function. Connecting Europe Facility Connecting Europe Facility SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1153 establishing the Connecting Europe Facility WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) to accelerate investment in the field of trans-European networks and to leverage funding from both the public and the private sectors, while increasing legal certainty and respecting the principle of technological neutrality. KEY POINTS The CEF is a multiannual financial framework (MFF) programme that supports the development of trans-European networks in the transport, energy and digital sectors. It aims to accelerate investment in the field of trans-European networks and to leverage funding from both the public and the private sectors, while increasing legal certainty and respecting the principle of technological neutrality. It also contributes to the goals and objectives of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The CEF is a multiannual financial framework (MFF) programme that supports the development of trans-European networks in the transport, energy and digital sectors. It lays down the objectives of the CEF, its budget for the period 2021-2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. The CEF is a multiannual financial framework (MFF) programme that supports the development of trans-European networks in the transport, energy and digital sectors. It lays down the objectives of the CEF, its budget for the period 2021-2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. The CEF is a multiannual financial framework (MFF) programme that supports the development of trans-European networks in the transport, energy and digital sectors. It lays down the objectives of the CEF, its budget for the period 2021-2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. It has applied since 1 January 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Connecting Europe Facility (European Commission). KEY TERMS Cross-border link: a project of common interest which ensures the continuity of the TEN-T between Member States or between a Member State and a third country. Terrorist content online: addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online Terrorist content online: addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/784 on addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure the smooth functioning of the digital single market in an open and democratic society by addressing the misuse of hosting services for terrorist purposes and contributing to public security across the EU. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out rules to address the misuse of hosting services for terrorist purposes and contribute to public security across the EU. It lays down a definition of terrorist content for preventative purposes, consistent with the definitions of relevant offences under Directive (EU) 2017/541. The regulation also sets out measures to be put in place by EU countries to: identify and ensure the removal of terrorist content; facilitate cooperation between the competent authorities of EU countries, hosting service providers and Europol. The regulation also sets out a number of measures to be taken by hosting service providers to address the dissemination of terrorist content online. The regulation also sets out a number of measures to be taken by hosting service providers to address the dissemination of terrorist content online. The regulation also sets out a number of measures to be taken by hosting service providers to address the dissemination of terrorist content online. The regulation also sets out a number of measures to be taken by hosting service providers to address the dissemination of terrorist content online. Space: EU’s space programme Space: EU’s space programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/696 establishing the Union Space Programme and the European Union Agency for the Space Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the EU Space Programme (EUSP) and the European Union Agency for the Space Programme (EUASP). It aims to promote scientific and technical progress and support the competitiveness and innovation capacity of the space sector industries within the EU, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), start-ups and innovative businesses. KEY POINTS The programme is financed by the European Union (EU) budget, which is based on the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the European Social Fund Plus (ESF Plus). The EUSP is a multiannual financial framework programme, which covers the following areas: research and technology development; applications and services; research and innovation; public demand and public sector innovation; space-related innovation partnerships; and the use of data, information and services. Digital Europe Programme Digital Europe Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/694 establishing the Digital Europe Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Digital Europe Programme (DEP) for the period 2021-2027. It aims to support and accelerate the digital transformation of the European economy, industry and society, to bring its benefits to citizens, public administrations and businesses across the EU, and to improve the competitiveness of Europe in the global digital economy while contributing to bridging the digital divide across the EU and reinforcing the Union’s strategic autonomy. KEY POINTS The DEP is a seven-year programme designed to support the digital transformation of the European economy, industry and society, to bring its benefits to citizens, public administrations and businesses across the EU, and to improve the competitiveness of Europe in the global digital economy while contributing to bridging the digital divide across the EU and reinforcing the Union’s strategic autonomy. The DEP is a seven-year programme designed to support the digital transformation of the European economy, industry and society, to bring its benefits to citizens, public administrations and businesses across the EU, and to improve the competitiveness of Europe in the global digital economy while contributing to bridging the digital divide across the EU and reinforcing the Union’s strategic autonomy. The DEP is implemented in close coordination with other EU programmes as applicable, and aims: to strengthen and promote Europe’s capacities in key digital technology areas through large-scale deployment; in the private sector and in areas of public interest, to widen the diffusion and uptake of Europe’s key digital technologies, promoting the digital transformation and access to digital technologies; to support the development of advanced digital skills in areas covered by the programme in order to contribute to increasing Europe’s talent pool, bridge the digital divide and foster greater professionalism. The DEP is implemented through a series of work programmes, including: High Performance Computing; Artificial Intelligence; Cybersecurity and Trust; Advanced Digital Skills; Deployment and Best Use of Digital Capacities and Interoperability. The DEP is implemented through a series of work programmes, including: High Performance Computing; Artificial Intelligence; Cybersecurity and Trust; Advanced Digital Skills; Deployment and Best Use of Digital Capacities and Interoperability. EU single market programme EU single market programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/690 establishing a programme for the internal market, competitiveness of enterprises, including small and medium-sized enterprises, the area of plants, animals, food and feed, and European statistics WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the functioning of the internal market, the competitiveness and sustainability of enterprises, especially micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and consumer protection, for the management of expenditure in the area of plants, animals, food and feed, and for the programming and financing framework used for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics. It repeals Regulations (EU) No 99/2013, (EU) No 1287/2013, (EU) No 254/2014 and (EU) No 652/2014. KEY POINTS The programme aims to improve the functioning of the internal market, the competitiveness and sustainability of enterprises, especially micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumer protection, for the management of expenditure in the area of plants, animals, food and feed, and for the programming and financing framework used for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics. It repeals Regulations (EU) No 99/2013, (EU) No 1287/2013, (EU) No 254/2014 and (EU) No 652/2014. The programme also aims to improve the application of the principle of mutual recognition in the area of goods, realising its full potential. It also aims to reduce the number of illegal and non-compliant goods entering the market through targeted awareness raising and training, support for Product Contact Points referred to in Regulation (EU) 2019/515 and better cooperation among competent authorities for mutual recognition. Control of the acquisition and possession of weapons Control of the acquisition and possession of weapons SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2021/555 on control of the acquisition and possession of weapons WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure that all firearms and their essential components are traced and identified. It aims to ensure that the EU’s internal market is streamlined and that the exchange of information between EU countries is efficient. KEY POINTS The directive applies to all firearms and their essential components, including: firearms manufactured or imported into the EU on or after 14 September 2018, and registered in compliance with the directive; firearms and their essential components, including: the type, make, model, calibre and serial number of each firearm and the mark applied to its frame or receiver as a unique marking; the serial number or unique marking applied to the essential components, where that differs from the marking on the frame or receiver of each firearm; the names and addresses of the suppliers and of the persons acquiring or possessing the firearm, together with the relevant date or dates; and any conversions or modifications to a firearm leading to a change in its category or subcategory, including its certified deactivation or destruction and the relevant date or dates. The directive does not apply to the acquisition or possession of weapons and ammunition, in accordance with national law, by the armed forces, the police or the public authorities. The directive does not apply to the acquisition or possession of weapons and ammunition, in accordance with national law, by the armed forces, the police or the public authorities. The directive does not apply to the acquisition or possession of weapons and ammunition, in accordance with national law, by the armed forces, the police or the public authorities. European Maritime Single Window environment European Maritime Single Window environment SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1239 establishing a European Maritime Single Window environment WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to simplify and harmonise the reporting obligations of ships arriving in and departing from EU ports in order to facilitate and expedite maritime transport. It aims to reduce administrative burdens for shipping companies by establishing a European Maritime Single Window (EMSWe) with harmonised interfaces. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a European Maritime Single Window (EMSWe) with harmonised interfaces, in order to facilitate the electronic transmission of information in relation to reporting obligations for ships arriving at, staying in and departing from a EU port. The EMSWe data set includes: a reference list of ship particulars and their reporting exemptions; a common location database; a common hazmat database; a common ship sanitation database. The regulation establishes a multiannual implementation plan to ensure the timely implementation of the EMSWe and to provide quality control mechanisms and procedures for deploying, maintaining and updating the EMSWe. The Commission adopts, and revises, a yearly implementation plan which provides: a plan for the development and updating of the EMSWe and the related harmonised elements of the EMSWe over the following 18 months; a plan for the development of the common addressing service by 15 August 2024; indicative dates for consultation with relevant stakeholders; indicative deadlines for the Commission’s development of a common addressing service following the implementation of the harmonised reporting interface module; Electronic road toll systems and facilitating cross-border exchange of information on the failure to pay road fees Electronic road toll systems and facilitating cross-border exchange of information on the failure to pay road fees SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/520 on the interoperability of electronic road toll systems and facilitating cross-border exchange of information on the failure to pay road fees in the EU WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure the interoperability of electronic road toll systems (EETS) on the entire EU road network, urban and interurban motorways, major and minor roads, and various structures, such as tunnels or bridges, and ferries. It also aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange of vehicle registration data regarding the vehicles and the owners or holders of vehicles for which there was a failure to pay road fees of any kind in the EU. KEY POINTS The directive applies to all new electronic road toll systems which require the installation or use of OBE (e.g. satellite positioning, mobile communications or 5,8 GHz microwave technology). The directive sets out the rules for registering EETS providers and ensuring that they are remunerated by the toll charger. The directive also sets out the rules for establishing a single contact office for EETS providers. The directive also sets out the rules for establishing a conciliation body to facilitate mediation between toll chargers with an EETS domain located within its territory and EETS providers that have contracts or are in contractual negotiations with those toll chargers. The directive also sets out the rules for establishing a single contact office for EETS providers. The directive also sets out the rules for establishing a single contact office for EETS providers. The directive also sets out the rules for establishing a single contact office for EETS providers. The directive also sets out the rules for establishing a single contact office for EETS providers. The directive also sets out the rules for establishing a single contact office for EETS providers. FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY? It has applied since 19 March 2019. EU countries had to incorporate it into national law by 19 April 2023. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Electronic road toll systems (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Directive (EU) 2019/520 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 19 March 2019 on the interoperability of electronic road toll systems and facilitating cross-border exchange of information on the failure to pay road fees in the Union (OJ L 91, 29.3.2019, pp. 45–46) Successive amendments to Directive (EU) 2019/520 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2019/520 of 19 October 2019 on the laying down the details for the classification of vehicles for the purposes of establishing the applicable tariff schemes, including any procedures necessary for establishing such schemes, and amending Directives 2014/53/EU (13) and 2014/30/EU (14) of the European Parliament and of the Council (OJ L 91, 29.3.2019, pp. 1-2) See consolidated version. last update 04.02.2021

It establishes a framework for interoperability between EU information systems in the field of borders and visa. It aims to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of border checks at external borders, contribute to the prevention and combating illegal immigration, contribute to a high level of security within the area of freedom, security and justice of the EU, including the maintenance of public security and public policy and safeguarding security in the territories of the Member States. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a European search portal (ESP) to facilitate the fast, seamless, efficient, systematic and controlled access of EU authorities and EU agencies to the EU information systems, to Europol data and to the Interpol databases. The ESP is composed of: a central infrastructure, including a search portal enabling the simultaneous querying of the EES, VIS, ETIAS, Eurodac, SIS, Eurodac, ECRIS-TCN as well as of Europol data and the Interpol databases; a secure communication channel between the ESP, EU authorities and EU agencies that are entitled to use the ESP; a secure communication infrastructure between the ESP and the EES, VIS, ETIAS, Eurodac, Central SIS, ECRIS-TCN, Europol data and the Interpol databases as well as between the ESP and the central infrastructures of the CIR and the MID. Renewable energy: promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources Renewable energy: promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2018/2001 on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to promote the use of energy from renewable sources (renewable energy) in the EU. It sets out a binding EU target of a share of at least 32 % of renewable energy in energy consumption and in the transport sector by 2020. It also sets out a financial framework to facilitate investments in renewable energy projects in those EU countries. KEY POINTS The directive sets out a binding EU renewable energy target of at least 32 % of renewable energy in energy consumption and in the transport sector by 2020. Electronic communications: a single European electronic communications code Electronic communications: a single European electronic communications code SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2018/1972 establishing the European Electronic Communications Code WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure freedom to provide electronic communications networks and services, subject only to the conditions laid down in this directive and to any restrictions in accordance with Article 52(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). It aims to ensure the protection of its essential security interests, safeguard public policy and public security, and permit the investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offences. KEY POINTS The directive lays down a single European electronic communications code (EEC) for all electronic communications networks and services, including the use of radio spectrum. It also covers the use of interpersonal communications services, which enable interpersonal and interactive exchange of information, and services consisting wholly or mainly in the conveyance of signals. Monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles Monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/956 on the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the requirements for the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles registered in the EU. It applies to the following vehicle categories: vehicles of categories M1, M2, N1 and N2 with a reference mass that exceeds 2 610 kg and which do not fall within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council (13), and all vehicles of categories O3 and O4. The data must be reported to the European Commission by 28 February each year. The Commission must monitor the results of on-road verification tests to verify the CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles. The Commission must publish an annual report with its analysis of the data transmitted by EU countries and manufacturers for the preceding calendar year. The analysis must indicate, as a minimum, the performance of the heavy-duty vehicle fleet of the EU as well as that of each EU country and each manufacturer in terms of the average fuel consumption and CO2 emissions for each heavy-duty vehicle group by mission profile, load and fuel combination. The Commission must also take into account data on the uptake of new and advanced CO2 reducing technologies, as well as of alternative powertrains. The Commission must prepare the analysis with the support of the European Environment Agency. The Commission must adopt delegated acts to supplement this regulation by laying down the procedure, methods for the calculation and collection of administrative fines. The Commission is assisted by the Climate Change Committee established by Regulation (EU) No 525/2013. The Commission must draw up a report in respect of the delegation of power by 29 July 2018. Security of gas supply Security of gas supply SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/1938 — measures to safeguard the security of gas supply WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure the proper and continuous functioning of the internal market in natural gas (gas) by allowing for exceptional measures to be implemented when the market can no longer deliver the gas supplies required, including solidarity measure of a last resort. It also establishes transparent mechanisms concerning, in a spirit of solidarity, the coordination of planning for, and response to, emergencies at national, regional and Union level. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a Gas Coordination Group (GCG) to facilitate the coordination of measures concerning the security of gas supply. The GCG is composed of representatives of the EU countries, in particular representatives of their competent authorities, as well as the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (the ‘Agency’), ENTSOG and representative bodies of the industry concerned and those of relevant customers. The GCG is responsible for assessing the risks identified in the common and national risk assessments and for preparing the preventive action plans and the emergency plans. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. The GCG is also responsible for coordinating the measures to deal with an emergency, with the Energy Community Contracting Parties and with other third countries. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 October 2017. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Security of gas supply’ on the European Commission's website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2017/1938 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2017 concerning measures to safeguard the security of gas supply and repealing Regulation (EU) No 994/2010 (OJ L 280, 28.10.2017, pp. 1–10) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2017/1938 have been incorporated into the original text. It aims to ensure that the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data is a fundamental right. It aims to ensure that the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data is a fundamental right. It aims to contribute to the accomplishment of an area of freedom, security and justice and of an economic union, to economic and social progress, to the strengthening and convergence of the economies within the internal market, and to the well-being of natural persons. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all natural persons, whatever their nationality or place of residence, in relation to the processing of their personal data. It lays down a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP, HICP-CT, OOH price index) and of the house price index (HPI) at EU and national level. KEY POINTS The harmonised index of consumer prices (HICP) and the harmonised index of consumer prices at constant tax rates (HICP-CT) are broken down into categories of the European classification of individual consumption according to purpose (ECOICOP). Anti-Dumping rules: protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the EU Anti-Dumping rules: protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the EU SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/1036 on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that the rules of the 1994 Anti-Dumping Agreement (ADA) are applied correctly and transparently. It lays down the procedures for pursuing an investigation, the imposition of provisional and definitive anti-dumping duties, the duration and review of anti-dumping measures and the public disclosure of information relating to anti-dumping investigations. KEY POINTS A product is considered as being dumped if its export price to the EU is less than a comparable price for a like product, in the ordinary course of trade, as established for the exporting country. The exporting country normally is the country of origin, except where, for example, the products are merely transhipped through that country, or the products concerned are not produced in that country, or there is no comparable price for them in that country. The normal value is calculated on the basis of the cost of production in the country of origin plus a reasonable amount for selling, general and administrative costs and for profits, or on the basis of the export prices, in the ordinary course of trade, to an appropriate third country, provided that those prices are representative. Technical support instrument Technical support instrument SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/240 establishing a technical support instrument WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a technical support instrument to help EU countries implement reforms. It is designed to encourage investment, increase competitiveness and achieve sustainable economic and social convergence, resilience and recovery. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a technical support instrument to help EU countries implement reforms. It is designed to encourage investment, increase competitiveness and achieve sustainable economic and social convergence, resilience and recovery. It also supports EU countries’ efforts to strengthen their institutional and administrative capacity, including at regional and local level, to facilitate socially inclusive, green and digital transitions, to effectively address the challenges identified in the country-specific recommendations and to implement EU law. The regulation sets out the general objective and specific objectives of the instrument, the budget of the instrument for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. The regulation also sets out the financial envelope for the instrument for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027. The instrument may also cover expenses pertaining to preparatory, monitoring, control, audit and evaluation activities which are required for the management of the instrument and the achievement of its objectives, in particular studies, meetings of experts, information and communication actions, including corporate communication of the political priorities of the Union, in so far as they are related to the objectives of this regulation, expenses linked to IT networks focusing on information processing and exchange, including corporate information technology tools, and all other technical and administrative assistance expenses incurred by the Commission for the management of the instrument. The regulation also sets out the financial envelope for the instrument for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027. The instrument may also cover expenses pertaining to preparatory, monitoring, control, audit and evaluation activities which are required for the management of the instrument and the achievement of its objectives, in particular studies, meetings of experts, information and communication actions, including corporate communication of the political priorities of the Union, in so far as they are related to the objectives of this regulation, expenses linked to IT networks focusing on information processing and exchange, including corporate information technology tools, and all other technical and administrative assistance expenses incurred by the Commission for the management of the instrument. Summary 27:
Passengers’ rights and obligations Passengers’ rights and obligations SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/782 on rail passengers’ rights and obligations WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to protect passengers’ rights and obligations in the event of an accident arising from the use of rail services and resulting in death, personal injury or loss of, or damage to, their luggage. It aims to ensure that passengers receive as precise information as possible on their rights. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to international and domestic rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Directive 2012/34/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council. The regulation does not apply to essential rules, in particular not to those relating to non-discriminatory conditions of transport contracts, to the right to purchase rail tickets without undue difficulty, to the liability of railway undertakings and their insurance obligations for passengers and their luggage, to the requirement that railway undertakings be adequately insured and to the requirement that adequate measures be taken to ensure passengers’ personal security in railway stations and on trains. The regulation also lays down rules on the handling of complaints and on the enforcement of the regulation. KEY TERMS Bicycles: bicycles that can be readily ridden prior to and after the rail journey. Passengers’ rights and obligations The regulation sets out the rights and obligations of railway undertakings, ticket vendors and tour operators in the event of an accident arising from the use of rail services and resulting in death, personal injury or loss of, or damage to, their luggage. The regulation also sets out the rights and obligations of railway undertakings, ticket vendors and tour operators in the event of disruption, such as cancellation or delay, including their right to compensation. The regulation also sets out the rules on the handling of complaints and on the enforcement of the regulation. The regulation also sets out the rules on the handling of complaints. The regulation also sets out the rules on the enforcement of the regulation. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 6 June 2021. EU countries had to incorporate it into national law by 7 June 2023. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Passengers’ rights and obligations (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2021/782 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 29 April 2021 on rail passengers’ rights and obligations (recast) (OJ L 172, 17.5.2021, pp. 1–22) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2021/782 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/947 establishing the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe (the ‘Instrument’), which is a programme for the purpose of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2021-2027. It lays down the objectives of the Instrument, the budget for the period from 2021-2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. KEY POINTS The instrument supports the EU’s external action, in particular to: reduce and, in the long term, the eradication of poverty; consolidate, support and promote democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights; sustainable development and the fight against climate change; address irregular migration and forced displacement, including their root causes; contribute to the promotion of multilateralism, the achievement of the international commitments and objectives that the EU has agreed to, in particular the SDGs, the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement; promote stronger partnerships with third countries, including with the European Neighbourhood Policy countries based on mutual interests and ownership with a view to fostering stabilisation, good governance and building resilience. The instrument also supports the implementation of the European Neighbourhood Policy, as reviewed in 2015 and endorsed by the Council in its conclusions of 14 December 2015, while maintaining an adequate geographical balance, and the implementation of regional cooperation frameworks, such as cross-border cooperation, transnational and maritime cooperation as well as the external aspects of relevant macro-regional and sea basin strategies and policies in the eastern and southern neighbourhood, including the Northern Dimension and the Black Sea regional cooperation, as well as the integrated Union policy for the Arctic. The instrument also supports the implementation of the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, and allow the Union and its ACP partners to develop further strong alliances on key global challenges. The instrument also contributes to the trade-related aspects of the Union’s external relations including supply-chain due diligence in order to ensure consistency and mutual support between Union trade policy and development goals and actions. The instrument also contributes to the trade-related aspects of the Union’s external relations including supply-chain due diligence in order to ensure consistency and mutual support between Union trade policy and development goals and actions. Protection of persons who report breaches of EU law Protection of persons who report breaches of EU law SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/1937 on the protection of persons who report breaches of EU law WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to enhance the enforcement of EU law and policies in specific areas by laying down common minimum standards providing for a high level of protection of persons reporting breaches of EU law. It aims to enhance the enforcement of EU law and policies in specific areas by laying down common minimum standards providing for a high level of protection of persons reporting breaches of EU law. KEY POINTS The directive lays down minimum standards for the protection of persons reporting breaches of EU law: breaches falling within the scope of the EU acts set out in the annexes to the directive; breaches affecting the financial interests of the EU as referred to in Article 325 TFEU and as further specified in relevant EU measures; breaches relating to the internal market, including breaches of Union competition and State aid rules, as well as breaches relating to acts which breach the rules of corporate tax or to arrangements the purpose of which is to obtain a tax advantage that defeats the object or purpose of the applicable corporate tax law. European Border and Coast Guard European Border and Coast Guard SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1896 on the European Border and Coast Guard WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a European Border and Coast Guard (ECCG) to ensure European integrated border management at the external borders with a view to managing those borders efficiently in full compliance with fundamental rights and to increasing the efficiency of the Union return policy. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a standing corps of 10 000 operational staff to support EU countries in their efforts to protect the external borders, fight cross-border crime and significantly step up the effective and sustainable return of irregular migrants. The standing corps is composed of 4 categories of operational staff, namely statutory staff, staff seconded to the Agency by EU countries for a long term, staff provided by EU countries for short-term deployments and staff forming part of the reserve for rapid reaction for rapid border interventions. The standing corps is composed of 4 categories of operational staff, namely statutory staff, staff seconded to the Agency by EU countries for a long term, staff provided by EU countries for short-term deployments and staff forming part of the reserve for rapid reaction for rapid border interventions. Harmonisation of gross national income at market prices Harmonisation of gross national income at market prices SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/516 on the harmonisation of gross national income at market prices and repealing Council Directive 89/130/EEC, Euratom and Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1287/2003 (GNI Regulation) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that the European Union (EU)’s gross national income (GNI) and gross domestic product (GDP) are comparable, reliable and exhaustive. KEY POINTS The regulation defines and defines gross national income at market prices (GNI) and gross domestic product at market prices (GDP) in accordance with the European System of Accounts 2010 (ESA 2010). The regulation sets out the procedures for calculating GNI and the methods used to compile GNI. The regulation sets out the structure and detailed arrangements of the inventory of the sources and methods used to produce GNI aggregates and their components. The regulation establishes a formal expert group composed of representatives of all the EU countries and chaired by a representative of the Commission. The Commission establishes a formal expert group, composed of representatives of all the EU countries and chaired by a representative of the Commission, to advise the Commission on, and to express its views regarding, the comparability, reliability and exhaustiveness of GNI calculations, to examine issues of implementation of this regulation and to issue annual opinions on the appropriateness of the GNI data submitted by the EU countries for own resources purposes. The Commission establishes a formal expert group, composed of representatives of all the EU countries and chaired by a representative of the Commission, to advise the Commission on, and to express its views regarding, the comparability, reliability and exhaustiveness of GNI calculations, to examine issues of implementation of this regulation and to issue annual opinions on the appropriateness of the GNI data submitted by the EU countries for own resources purposes. European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/794 on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) and replacing and repealing Council Decisions 2009/371/JHA, 2009/934/JHA, 2009/935/JHA, 2009/936/JHA and 2009/968/JHA WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). It replaces and succeeds Europol as established by Decision 2009/371/JHA. KEY POINTS Europol is a law enforcement agency that supports and strengthens action by the competent authorities of the EU countries and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries. European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/672 — establishment of a European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency (SURE) following the COVID-19 outbreak. It complements national measures taken by affected EU countries by providing financial assistance to help those countries cope with the sudden and severe increase in actual and possibly also planned public expenditure intended to mitigate the direct economic, social and health-related effects of the exceptional occurrence caused by the COVID-19 outbreak. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the conditions and procedures for granting financial assistance to a EU country which is experiencing, or is seriously threatened with, a severe economic disturbance caused by the COVID-19 outbreak for the financing, primarily, of short-time work schemes or similar measures aimed at protecting employees and the self-employed and thus reducing the incidence of unemployment and loss of income, as well as for the financing, as an ancillary, of some health-related measures, in particular in the workplace. The instrument complements the national measures taken by affected EU countries by providing financial assistance to help those countries cope with the sudden and severe increase in actual and possibly also planned public expenditure intended to mitigate the direct economic, social and health-related effects of the exceptional occurrence caused by the COVID-19 outbreak. The instrument is of a temporary nature in order to address the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak on the economic system of each EU country. The instrument complements the national measures taken by affected EU countries by providing financial assistance to help those countries cope with the sudden and severe increase in actual and possibly also planned public expenditure intended to mitigate the direct economic, social and health-related effects of the exceptional occurrence caused by the COVID-19 outbreak. Recovery and resolution of central counterparties Recovery and resolution of central counterparties SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/23 on a framework for the recovery and resolution of central counterparties and amending Regulations (EU) No 1095/2010, (EU) No 648/2012, (EU) No 600/2014, (EU) No 806/2014 and (EU) 2015/2365 and Directives 2002/47/EC, 2004/25/EC, 2007/36/EC, 2014/59/EU and (EU) 2017/1132 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that central counterparties (CCPs) are able to recover from financial distress and to restore their viability. It aims to ensure that the CCPs that are subject to prudential requirements are able to recover from financial distress and to restore their viability. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the recovery and resolution rules for CCPs. The regulation sets out the recovery plans and the conditions for resolution. The resolution plans are drawn up by the resolution authority of the CCP and jointly agreed in the resolution college. The resolution plan covers a broad range of scenarios, distinguishing scenarios resulting from default events, non-default events and a combination of both, as well as different types of non-default events. The resolution plan should be non-discriminatory and balanced in terms of its impact and the incentives it creates. The effects of the recovery measures on clearing members and, where relevant, their clients and on the financial system of the EU or of one or more of its Member States more broadly should be proportionate. The resolution framework should provide for timely entry into resolution before a CCP is insolvent. The resolution authority should have at its disposal a harmonised set of resolution tools and powers. European Year of Rail 2021 European Year of Rail 2021 SUMMARY OF: Decision (EU) 2020/2228 on a European Year of Rail WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It sets out the objectives of the European Year of Rail (the ‘European Year’) to encourage and support the efforts of the EU, Member States, regional and local authorities, and other organisations to increase the share of passengers and freight moving by rail. The objectives of the European Year are to: promote rail as a sustainable, innovative, interconnected and intermodal, safe and affordable mode of transport; highlight the role of rail as a game changer helping to achieve the EU’s climate neutrality objective by 2050; pillar of an efficient logistic network, capable of guaranteeing essential services, even during unexpected crises; promote rail as an important element in relations between the EU and its neighbouring countries, building on interests and needs in partner countries and on expertise in rail transport, both within and beyond the EU; build on rail’s power to stimulate the collective imagination, particularly through rail’s history and its cultural heritage, recalling the contribution that rail has made to the creation of European prosperity and the role of the rail in developing cutting-edge technologies; promote the attractiveness of the railway professions, in particular by highlighting the demand for new skills and the importance of fair and safe working conditions and of addressing the need to increase diversity in the workforce; promote the key role of railways in international passenger transport within the EU; promote a Union night train network and encourage initiatives that underline its cross-border nature by using symbols that represent the Union; create public awareness of rail’s potential role in the development of sustainable tourism in Europe; promote the key role of railways in sustainable end-to-end mobility, connecting hubs and allowing attractive and smart transfer between modes of transport; contribute to the implementation of the Fourth Railway Package and to raising awareness of the measures required to establish the single European railway area, based on a well-functioning TEN-T; stimulate discussion on how to modernise rolling stock and on how to further develop and increase the capacity of railway infrastructure in order to facilitate the broader use of passenger and freight transport by rail; promote events and initiatives to disseminate information on the rights of rail passengers and to stimulate cooperation among all actors in order to improve customer information and ticketing, including the offer of through-tickets and developing innovative digital multi-modal tickets, as well as to provide information about current challenges in that respect, such as the need for data sharing among actors. The measures to be taken to achieve the objectives set out in the European Year are closely coordinated with on-going activities promoting rail transport. These measures include the following activities at Union, national, regional or local level, organised in partnerships or individually, and linked to the objectives of the European Year: initiatives and events to promote debate, build a positive image, raise awareness and facilitate the engagement of citizens, businesses and public authorities in order to increase trust in rail, particularly in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis, and to promote the attractiveness of rail for the transport of more people and goods as a means of combating climate change, through multiple channels and tools, including events in Member States, while also highlighting the safety and comfort of travelling by rail; initiatives in Member States to encourage, in both the public and private sector, business-travel and commuting patterns by rail; informative exhibitions, inspirational, educational and awareness-raising campaigns, as well as the use of demonstration and information trains to encourage changes in passenger, consumer and business behaviour and to stimulate the general public to actively contribute to achieving the objectives of more sustainable transport; sharing the experience and best practices of national, regional and local authorities, civil society, businesses and schools as regards promoting the use of rail and on how to implement behavioural change at all levels; undertaking studies and innovative activities, and disseminating their results on a European or national scale; promoting projects and networks related to the European Year, including via the media, social networks and other online communities; partnerships and events such as those set out in the Annex; identifying and promoting best practices to create a level-playing field for different modes of transport; promoting projects and activities to raise awareness of sustainable end-to-end mobility that delivers seamless ‘door-to-door’ travel solutions in combination with other modes of transport, including active travel, and sustainable and smart logistics; European Security and Defence College European Security and Defence College SUMMARY OF: Decision (CFSP) 2020/1515 establishing a European Security and Defence College WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It establishes the European Security and Defence College (ESDC) to provide training and education in the field of the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) in the wider context of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) at European level. KEY POINTS The ESDC is organised as a network bringing together civilian and military institutes, colleges, academies, universities, institutions, centres of excellence and other actors dealing with security and defence policy issues within the EU as identified by Member States, as well as the European Union Institute for Security Studies (EUISS). The ESDC is responsible for: organising and conducting ESDC training and education activities in the field of the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) in the wider context of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) at European level; providing training and education responding to training and educational needs of CSDP missions and operations; supporting EU partnerships in the field of CSDP, in particular partnerships with those countries participating in CSDP missions; supporting civilian crisis management including in the field of conflict prevention, and establishing or preserving the conditions necessary for sustainable development; promoting the European Initiative for the Exchange of Young Officers; promoting PhD-level research in domains related to CSDP; providing Member States’ and Union administrations with knowledgeable personnel familiar with EU policies, institutions, procedures and best practices in the field of cyber security and defence; helping promote professional relations and contacts among training and education participants. The ESDC is a member of the European External Action Service (EEAS), which provides the ESDC with the support previously provided by the General Secretariat of the Council. The ESDC is a party to legal proceedings. The ESDC is a member of the European Institute for Security Studies (EUISS), which provides lectures given by EUISS analysts and contributes to the further development of the ESDC e-Learning content. The ESDC is a member of the European Union Institute for Security Studies (EUISS). The ESDC is a party to legal proceedings. Reuse of treated urban waste water Reuse of treated urban waste water SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/741 on minimum requirements for water reuse WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that reclaimed water is safe for agricultural irrigation. It lays down minimum requirements for water quality and monitoring and provisions on risk management. It aims to ensure that reclaimed water is safe for agricultural irrigation. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to: urban waste water that has been treated in compliance with the requirements set out in Directive 91/271/EEC; and that results from further treatment in a reclamation facility. The quality of the water must be complied with at the point of compliance. The quality of the water must no longer be the responsibility of the reclamation facility operator. The quality of the water must be monitored. The quality of the water must be inspected every 2 years. The regulation sets out minimum requirements for water quality and monitoring and provisions on risk management. EU Blue Card: conditions of entry and residence of highly qualified workers EU Blue Card: conditions of entry and residence of highly qualified workers SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2021/1883 on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purpose of highly qualified employment WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to improve the conditions of entry and residence of highly qualified workers from non-EU countries. It repeals Directive 2009/50/EC, which aims to attract highly qualified workers from non-EU countries. KEY POINTS The directive sets out the conditions of entry and residence for more than 3 months in the territory of the EU countries, and the rights of third-country nationals for the purpose of highly qualified employment and their family members. The directive does not apply to: those seeking international protection and are awaiting a decision on their status or who are beneficiaries of temporary protection in accordance with Council Directive 2001/55/EC; those applying to reside in a Member State as researchers within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/801 in order to carry out a research project; those enjoying EU long-term resident status in a Member State in accordance with Directive 2003/109/EC and exercise their right to reside in another Member State in order to carry out an economic activity in an employed or self-employed capacity; those entering a Member State under commitments contained in an international agreement facilitating the entry and temporary stay of certain categories of trade- and investment-related natural persons, with the exception of third-country nationals who have been admitted to the territory of a Member State as intra-corporate transferees pursuant to Directive 2014/66/EU; whose expulsion has been suspended for reasons of fact or law; those who are covered by Directive 96/71/EC for the duration of their posting to the territory of the Member State concerned; or those who, under agreements between the EU and the Member States on the one hand, and non-EU countries on the other, enjoy rights of free movement equivalent to those of EU citizens. The directive does not affect the right of Member States to determine volumes of admission of third-country nationals coming from non-EU countries to their territory in order to seek work. The directive does not affect the right of Member States to determine volumes of admission of third-country nationals coming from non-EU countries to their territory in order to seek work. Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1147 establishing the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027. It lays down the objectives of the fund, the budget for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. KEY POINTS The fund supports the EU’s common policy on asylum and immigration, in particular by: strengthening and developing the common European asylum system; strengthening and developing legal migration to the EU countries in accordance with their economic and social needs; countering irregular migration; enhancing effective, safe and dignified return and readmission; and promoting and contributing to effective initial reintegration in third countries. The fund also supports the EU’s efforts to fully implement and further develop the Common European Asylum System, including its external dimension. The fund supports the EU’s efforts to fully implement and further develop the Common European Asylum System, including its external dimension. Work-life balance for parents and carers Work-life balance for parents and carers SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/1158 on work-life balance for parents and carers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure that men and women who have an employment contract or employment relationship are treated equally in the labour market. It aims to promote equal treatment between men and women in the workplace. KEY POINTS The directive lays down minimum requirements for the uptake of paternity, parental leave and carers’ leave by men and women. Summary 46:
European framework for the provision of better services for skills and qualifications (Europass) European framework for the provision of better services for skills and qualifications (Europass) SUMMARY OF: Decision (EU) 2018/646 on a common framework for the provision of better services for skills and qualifications (Europass) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It establishes a European framework to support the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings, including through practical experiences, mobility and volunteering. It aims to help users to better communicate and present skills and qualifications and to compare qualifications. KEY POINTS The decision establishes a European framework to support the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings, including through practical experiences, mobility and volunteering. It consists of web-based tools and relevant available information, including information to support the European dimension of guidance provided through an online platform and supported by national services intended to help users to better communicate and present skills and qualifications and to compare qualifications. The online platform is targeted at: individual end-users, such as learners, job seekers, workers and volunteers, and relevant stakeholders, such as education and training providers, guidance practitioners, employers, public employment services, social partners, youth work providers, youth organisations and policy makers. The use of Europass tools for the assessment of skills and self-assessment of skills is not directly to formal recognition or the issuance of qualifications. The online platform provides available information or links to available information on the following topics: learning opportunities; qualifications and qualifications frameworks or systems; opportunities for validation of non-formal and informal learning; recognition practices and relevant legislation in different countries, including third countries; services offering guidance for transnational learning mobility and career management; skills intelligence as produced by relevant Union-level activities and agencies within their domains of competence; information on skills and qualifications that could be relevant to the particular needs of third country nationals arriving or residing in the Union to support their integration. The Commission manages the Europass online platform, which is user-friendly and secure and is made available free-of-charge to all users. The Commission must: ensure the availability and high quality of Union-level information or links to such available information; develop, test and, when necessary, update the Europass online platform, including open standards, in line with user needs and technological advancements as well as changes in labour markets and in the provision of education and training; keep up to date with and incorporate, where relevant, the latest technological developments that can improve the accessibility of Europass for older persons and persons with disabilities; ensure that any development or updating of the Europass online platform, including open standards, supports consistency of information and demonstrates clear added value; ensure that any web-based tools, in particular tools for assessment and self-assessment, are fully tested and quality-assured; ensure the quality and monitor the effectiveness of the Europass online platform including web-based tools in line with user needs. The Commission must report on progress and expected future developments following the adoption of this Decision, as appropriate, in the context of relevant education, training and employment policy frameworks. FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY? It has applied since 18 April 2018. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Europass (European Commission). KEY TERMS Qualification: a formal outcome of an assessment and validation process which is obtained when a competent authority or body determines that an individual has achieved learning outcomes to given standards. Europass: a set of documents, such as diploma supplements and certificate supplements, issued by the competent authorities or bodies. Guidance: a continuous process that enables individuals to identify their capacities, skills and interests, through a range of individual and collective activities to make educational, training and occupational decisions and to manage their individual life paths in learning, work and other settings in which those capacities and skills are learned or used. MAIN DOCUMENT Decision (EU) 2018/646 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 April 2018 on a common framework for the provision of better services for skills and qualifications (Europass) and repealing Decision No 2241/2004/EC (OJ L 112, 2.5.2018, pp. 42–44) Successive amendments to Decision (EU) 2018/646 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Council Recommendation of 22 May 2017 on the European Qualifications Framework for lifelong learning and repealing the recommendation of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2008 on the establishment of the European Qualifications Framework for lifelong learning (OJ C 189, 15.6.2017, pp. 15–22) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.12.2012, pp. 15–17) Council Recommendation of 20 December 2012 on the validation of non-formal and informal learning (OJ C 398, 22.

It sets out common rules for the production of European statistics concerning inland waterways transport. Rail transport statistics Rail transport statistics SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/643 on rail transport statistics WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to establish common rules for the production of rail transport statistics at EU level. It aims to ensure that the data collected are harmonised and that they are available to the European Commission (Eurostat). KEY POINTS The regulation covers all railways in the EU. Each EU country must report statistics which relate to rail transport on its national territory. Where a railway undertaking operates in more than one EU country, the national authorities concerned must require the undertaking to provide data separately for each country in which it operates so as to enable national statistics to be compiled. The national authorities concerned must require the undertaking to provide data separately for each country in which it operates so as to enable national statistics to be compiled. The data collected are set out in the annexes to the regulation. They cover the following types of data: annual statistics on goods transport — detailed reporting (Annex I); annual statistics on passenger transport — detailed reporting (Annex II); quarterly statistics on goods and passenger transport (Annex III); regional statistics on goods and passenger transport (Annex IV); statistics on traffic flows on the rail network (Annex V). European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/1727 on the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust). It replaces and succeeds Council Decision 2002/187/JHA. KEY POINTS Eurojust is a European Union body with legal personality, to stimulate and to improve coordination and cooperation between competent judicial authorities of the Member States, particularly in relation to serious organised crime. It is governed by a regulation, adopted in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure. It also requires determining arrangements for involving the European Parliament and national parliaments in the evaluation of Eurojust’s activities. The regulation sets out the structure and organisation of Eurojust, including the national members, the College, the Executive Board and the Administrative Director.
