Resolution of banks Resolution of banks SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 establishing uniform rules and a uniform procedure for the resolution of credit institutions and certain investment firms in the framework of a Single Resolution Mechanism and a Single Resolution Fund WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that the EU’s prudential supervision of credit institutions is implemented in a coherent and effective manner, that the single rulebook for financial services is applied in the same manner to credit institutions in the euro area Member States and those non-euro area Member States who choose to participate in the Single Resolution Mechanism (SSM) and that those credit institutions are subject to supervision of the highest quality. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a single resolution mechanism (SRM) for all banks and financial institutions established in the participating Member States. It enables the SRM to be applied to banks and financial institutions established in the participating Member States and subject to the supervision of the European Central Bank (ECB) and the national authorities within the framework of the SSM. The SRM is interwoven with the process of harmonisation in the field of prudential supervision, brought about by the establishment of the European Supervisory Authority (European Banking Authority) (EBA) and the single rulebook on prudential supervision (Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council (7) and Directive 2013/36/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council (8)). The regulation also establishes a single resolution fund (SRM) for all participating Member States. It is financed by bank contributions raised at national level and pooled at EU level in accordance with an intergovernmental agreement on the transfer and progressive mutualisation of those contributions (the ‘Agreement’). The regulation also establishes a Single Resolution Board (SRB) to take decisions in relation to significant entities or groups, entities or groups directly supervised by the ECB or cross-border groups. The SRM is based on the frameworks of Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 and Directive 2014/59/EU. The SRM is a centralised power of resolution, entrusted to the Single Resolution Board and to the national resolution authorities. The SRM is interwoven with the process of harmonisation in the field of prudential supervision, brought about by the establishment of the European Supervisory Authority (European Banking Authority) (EBA) and the single rulebook on prudential supervision (Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council (7) and Directive 2013/36/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council (8)). Insolvency proceedings: EU rules on the administration of insolvency proceedings Insolvency proceedings: EU rules on the administration of insolvency proceedings SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of insolvency proceedings in the EU. It aims to ensure that the EU’s internal market is efficient and effective. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation covers all insolvency proceedings, including interim proceedings, which are based on laws relating to insolvency and in which, for the purpose of rescue, adjustment of debt, reorganisation or liquidation: a debtor is totally or partially divested of its assets and an insolvency practitioner is appointed; the assets and affairs of a debtor are subject to control or supervision by a court; or a temporary stay of individual enforcement proceedings is granted by a court or by operation of law, in order to allow for negotiations between the debtor and its creditors, provided that the proceedings in which the stay is granted provide for suitable measures to protect the general body of creditors, and, where no agreement is reached, are preliminary to one of the proceedings. The regulation also covers: the recognition and enforcement of judgments issued in such proceedings; the law applicable to insolvency proceedings; the coordination of insolvency proceedings which relate to the same debtor or to several members of the same group of companies. The regulation also sets out rules on cooperation, communication and coordination in the framework of insolvency proceedings. The regulation also sets out rules on the recognition and enforcement of judgments issued in such proceedings and on the law applicable to insolvency proceedings. The regulation also sets out rules on the coordination of insolvency proceedings which relate to the same debtor or to several members of the same group of companies. The regulation also sets out rules on the coordination of insolvency proceedings which relate to the same debtor or to several members of the same group of companies. The regulation also sets out rules on the coordination of insolvency proceedings which relate to the same debtor or to several members of the same group of companies. Liability of carriers of passengers by sea Liability of carriers of passengers by sea SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 392/2009 on the liability of carriers of passengers by sea in the event of accidents WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the EU’s liability and insurance rules for the carriage of passengers by sea. It aims to ensure that passengers are compensated for any damage caused by accidents. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to any international carriage within the meaning of point 9 of the Athens Convention and to carriage by sea within a single Member State on board ships of Class A and B under Article 4 of Directive 98/18/EC, where: the ship is flying the flag of or is registered in a Member State; the contract of carriage has been made in a Member State; or the place of departure or destination, according to the contract of carriage, is in a Member State. The regulation also extends the application of the rules to carriage of passengers by sea within a single Member State on board ships of Class C and D under Article 4 of Directive 98/18/EC, and lays down certain supplementary requirements. The regulation also extends the application of the rules to carriage of passengers by sea within a single Member State on board ships of Class C and D under Article 4 of Directive 98/18/EC, and lays down certain supplementary requirements. Reporting The regulation is accompanied by a report on the application of the regulation, which takes into account economic developments and developments in international fora. The Commission is assisted by the Committee on Safe Seas and the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (COSS). The regulation applies to any international carriage within the meaning of point 9 of the Athens Convention and to carriage by sea within a single Member State on board ships of Class A and B under Article 4 of Directive 98/18/EC, where: the ship is flying the flag of or is registered in a Member State; the contract of carriage has been made in a Member State; or the place of departure or destination, according to the contract of carriage, is in a Member State. Occupation of road transport operator Occupation of road transport operator SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 establishing common rules concerning the conditions to be complied with to pursue the occupation of road transport operator WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to modernise the rules governing admission to the occupation of road transport operator. It aims to ensure that these rules are applied more uniformly and effectively in the EU countries. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all undertakings established in the EU which are engaged in the occupation of road transport operator. It also applies to undertakings which intend to engage in such occupation. The regulation does not apply to: undertakings engaged in road passenger transport services exclusively for non-commercial purposes or which have a main occupation other than that of road transport operator; undertakings engaged in road haulage services exclusively for non-commercial purposes or which have a main occupation other than that of road transport operator; undertakings engaged in road passenger transport services solely by means of motor vehicles with a maximum authorised speed not exceeding 40 km/h. The regulation does not apply to: undertakings engaged in road haulage operator solely by means of motor vehicles or combinations of vehicles the permissible laden mass of which does not exceed 3,5 tonnes; undertakings engaged in road passenger transport services exclusively for non-commercial purposes or which have a main occupation other than that of road transport operator; undertakings engaged in road passenger transport services solely by means of motor vehicles with a maximum authorised speed not exceeding 40 km/h. Social security coordination: rules for implementing social security coordination Social security coordination: rules for implementing social security coordination SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 987/2009 — procedure for implementing Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 on the coordination of social security systems WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to modernise the rules on the coordination of social security systems, specifying the measures and procedures for implementing them and simplifying them for all the players involved. It lays down the rules for cooperation and exchanges of data between EU countries’ authorities and institutions and persons covered by the regulation. It also lays down the rules for the exchange of information between institutions and persons covered by the regulation. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the rules for cooperation and exchanges of data between EU countries’ authorities and institutions and persons covered by the regulation. The rules are based on the principles of public service, efficiency, active assistance, rapid delivery and accessibility, including e-accessibility, in particular for the disabled and the elderly. The institutions must without delay provide or exchange all data necessary for establishing and determining the rights and obligations of persons to whom the regulation applies. The institutions must forward the information and issue the documents to the persons concerned without delay and in all cases within any time limits specified under the legislation of the EU country in question. The institutions must notify the claimant residing or staying in another EU country of its decision directly or through the liaison body of the EU country of destination. When refusing the benefits, it must also indicate the reasons for refusal, the remedies and periods allowed for appeals. The institution of the place of residence must notify the claimant residing or staying in another EU country of its decision directly or through the liaison body of the EU country of destination. Where a person has mistakenly submitted information, documents or claims to an institution in the territory of a EU country other than that in which the institution designated in accordance with the implementing regulation is situated, the information, documents or claims must be resubmitted without delay by the former institution to the institution designated in accordance with the implementing regulation, indicating the date on which they were initially submitted. The institution of the place of residence must notify the claimant residing or staying in another EU country of its decision directly or through the liaison body of the EU country of destination. Statistics on public health and safety at work Statistics on public health and safety at work SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1338/2008 on Community statistics on public health and health and safety at work WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common framework for the systematic production of European Union (EU) statistics on public health and health and safety at work. The statistics are produced in compliance with standards on impartiality, reliability, objectivity, cost-effectiveness and statistical confidentiality. The statistics include, in the form of a harmonised and common data set, information required for Community action in the field of public health, for supporting national strategies for the development of high-quality, universally accessible and sustainable health care as well as for Community action in the field of health and safety at work. The statistics provide data for structural indicators, sustainable development indicators and European Community Health Indicators (ECHI), as well as for the other sets of indicators which it is necessary to develop for the purpose of monitoring Community actions in the fields of public health and health and safety at work. The statistics are produced in compliance with standards on impartiality, reliability, objectivity, cost-effectiveness and statistical confidentiality. Summary 147:
Statistics on job vacancies Statistics on job vacancies SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 453/2008 on quarterly statistics on Community job vacancies WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the requirements for the regular quarterly production of statistics on job vacancies* in the EU. It sets out the rules for the production of statistics on job vacancies* in the EU. KEY POINTS Each EU country must submit to Eurostat data on job vacancies at least for business units with one employee or more. The data cover all economic activities defined by the common classification system for economic activities in the EU (NACE). The data must be broken down by economic activity in accordance with the NACE in force. The data must distinguish, on an optional basis, between vacancies for fixed-term and permanent jobs. Reference dates and technical specifications Each EU country must compile the quarterly data with reference to specific reference dates, which must be determined in accordance with the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. The data must be provided using business surveys. Other sources, such as administrative data, may be used provided that they are appropriate in terms of quality. The sources of all data provided must be specified. The Commission (Eurostat) must assess the quality of the data transmitted. The Commission must set out the appropriate framework for the establishment of a series of feasibility studies. These studies must be undertaken by those EU countries that have difficulties in providing data for: units with fewer than 10 employees; and/or the following activities: public administration and defence; compulsory social security; education; human health and social work activities; arts, entertainments and recreation; and activities of membership organisations, repair of computers and personal and household goods and other personal service activities. The Commission must adopt measures in accordance with the results of the feasibility studies. The Commission must submit a report to the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of this regulation every 3 years. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 20 April 2008. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Job vacancy statistics’ on the European Commission's website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EC) No 453/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2008 on quarterly statistics on Community job vacancies (OJ L 145, 4.6.2008, pp. 234–354) Successive amendments to Regulation (EC) No 453/2008 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Type-approval of hydrogen-powered motor vehicles Type-approval of hydrogen-powered motor vehicles SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 79/2009 on type-approval of hydrogen-powered motor vehicles WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It harmonises the technical requirements for the type-approval of hydrogen-powered motor vehicles (HVs) and the installation of HVs. It aims to accelerate the placing on the market of vehicles with innovative propulsion technologies and vehicles which use alternative fuels with a low environmental impact. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to: hydrogen-powered vehicles of categories M and N, including impact protection and the electric safety of such vehicles; hydrogen components designed for motor vehicles of categories M and N, including new forms of hydrogen storage or usage; hydrogen systems designed for motor vehicles of categories M and N, including new forms of hydrogen storage or usage. Manufacturers must demonstrate that all new hydrogen-powered vehicles sold, registered or put into service within the EU and all hydrogen components or hydrogen systems sold or put into service within the EU are type-approved in accordance with this regulation and its implementing measures. Manufacturers must provide the approval authorities with appropriate information concerning the vehicle specifications and test conditions. Conditions for access to the natural gas transmission networks Conditions for access to the natural gas transmission networks SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 715/2009 — conditions for access to the natural gas transmission networks WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that the internal market in natural gas is functioning properly and to facilitate the emergence of a well-functioning and transparent wholesale market with a high level of security of supply in gas. It also aims to facilitate the emergence of a well-functioning and transparent wholesale market with a high level of security of supply in gas. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out rules for access to the natural gas transmission networks and the conditions for access to LNG facilities and storage facilities. The regulation sets out the rules for: access to the network, but not to storage facilities; the establishment of third-party access services and harmonised principles for capacity-allocation and congestion-management; the determination of transparency requirements, balancing rules and imbalance charges, and the facilitation of capacity trading. The regulation also sets out the rules for: the establishment of the European Network of Transmission System Operators for Gas (ENTSO for Gas); the development of network codes for providing and managing effective and transparent access to the transmission networks across borders; the establishment of the European Network of Transmission System Operators for Gas (ENTSO for Gas); the monitoring and analysis of the implementation of the network codes and the guidelines adopted by the Commission; the annual work programme for the ENTSO for Gas; the annual summer and winter supply outlooks. The ENTSO for Gas is responsible for: preparing the network codes; preparing the annual work programme; coordinating the ENTSO for Gas with other national authorities; coordinating technical cooperation between the ENTSO for Gas and other national authorities; preparing the annual supply outlook; preparing the annual work programme for the ENTSO for Gas. Summary 150:
Agreements with non-EU countries Agreements with non-EU countries SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 662/2009 — procedure for the negotiation and conclusion of agreements between EU countries and non-EU countries on particular matters concerning the law applicable to contractual and non-contractual obligations WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a procedure for the negotiation and conclusion of agreements between EU countries and non-EU countries on particular matters concerning the law applicable to contractual and non-contractual obligations. It does not apply to agreements with non-EU countries if the EU has already concluded an agreement with the non-EU country concerned on the same subject matter. KEY POINTS Notification to the Commission Where a EU country intends to enter into negotiations in order to amend an existing agreement or to conclude a new agreement falling within the scope of this regulation, it must notify the Commission in writing of its intention at the earliest possible moment before the envisaged opening of formal negotiations. The notification must include, as appropriate, a copy of the existing agreement, the draft agreement or the draft proposal, and any other relevant documentation. The Commission must assess whether the EU country has a specific interest in concluding the agreement due to economic, geographic, cultural, historical, social or political ties between the EU country and the non-EU country concerned. If this is not the case, the Commission must assess whether all of the following conditions are met: the EU country concerned has provided information showing that it has a specific interest in concluding the agreement due to economic, geographic, cultural, historical, social or political ties between the EU country and the non-EU country concerned; on the basis of the information provided by the EU country, the envisaged agreement appears not to render EU law ineffective and not to undermine the proper functioning of the system established by that law; and the envisaged agreement would not undermine the object and purpose of the EU’s external relations policy as decided by the EU. If the EU country does not request the Commission to enter into discussions with it, it must give an opinion to the EU country concerned within 90 days of receipt of the opinion. If the EU country does not request the Commission to enter into discussions with it, it must give a reasoned decision on the application of the EU country within 130 days of the closure of the discussions. The Commission may participate as an observer in the negotiations between the EU country and the non-EU country. The Commission may also participate as an observer in the negotiations between the EU country and the non-EU country. The Commission may also participate as an observer in the negotiations between the EU country and the non-EU country. Statistics on migration and international protection Statistics on migration and international protection SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 862/2007 on Community statistics on migration and international protection WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that EU countries collect and compile statistics on: immigration to and emigration from the EU’s territories, including flows from the territory of one EU country to that of another EU country and flows between a EU country and the territory of a non-EU country; the citizenship and country of birth of persons usually resident in the territory of the EU countries; administrative and judicial procedures and processes in the EU countries relating to immigration, granting of permission to reside, citizenship, asylum and other forms of international protection and the prevention of illegal immigration. KEY POINTS EU countries must supply to the European Commission (Eurostat) statistics on: immigration to and emigration from the EU’s territories, including flows from the territory of one EU country to that of another EU country and flows between a EU country and the territory of a non-EU country; the citizenship and country of birth of persons usually resident in the territory of the EU countries; administrative and judicial procedures and processes in the EU countries relating to immigration, granting of permission to reside, citizenship, asylum and other forms of international protection and the prevention of illegal immigration. The statistics must be based on the following data sources according to their availability in the EU country and in accordance with national laws and practices: records of administrative and judicial actions; registers relating to administrative actions; registers of the population of persons or of a particular sub-group of that population; censuses; sample surveys; other appropriate sources. Statutory audit of public-interest entities Statutory audit of public-interest entities SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 537/2014 on specific requirements regarding statutory audit of public-interest entities WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down requirements for the carrying out of the statutory audit of annual and consolidated financial statements of public-interest entities, rules on the organisation and selection of statutory auditors and audit firms by public-interest entities to promote their independence and the avoidance of conflicts of interest and rules on the supervision of compliance by statutory auditors and audit firms with those requirements. It repeals Commission Decision 2005/909/EC. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to the following: statutory auditors and audit firms carrying out statutory audits of public-interest entities; public-interest entities. The regulation sets out the rules for the organisation and selection of statutory auditors and audit firms by public-interest entities to promote their independence and the avoidance of conflicts of interest and rules on the supervision of compliance by statutory auditors and audit firms with those requirements. Common Fisheries Policy Common Fisheries Policy SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 on the Common Fisheries Policy WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the conservation and sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources under the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). It aims to ensure that fishing and aquaculture activities are environmentally sustainable in the long-term and are managed in a way that is consistent with the objectives of achieving economic, social and employment benefits, and of contributing to the availability of food supplies. KEY POINTS The regulation covers: the conservation of marine biological resources and the management of fisheries and fleets exploiting such resources; in relation to measures on markets and financial measures in support of the implementation of the CFP: fresh water biological resources, aquaculture, and the processing and marketing of fisheries and aquaculture products. Common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products Common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1379/2013 on the common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products (CMO) to ensure that the EU’s fisheries and aquaculture sectors are managed in a sustainable manner, improve the placing on the market of products, collect information on aquaculture and improve their incomes. KEY POINTS The CMO is comprised of: professional organisations; marketing standards; consumer information; competition rules; market intelligence. It is supplemented by Regulation (EU) No 1220/2012 and Regulation (EU) No 1026/2012. The CMO is eligible to receive EU financial support in accordance with a future EU legal act establishing the conditions for the financial support for maritime and fisheries policy for the period 2014–2020. The regulation also lays down rules on the recognition of producer organisations and inter-branch organisations, as well as on the extension of the rules of producer organisations and inter-branch organisations. The regulation also lays down rules on the internal functioning of producer organisations and inter-branch organisations. The regulation also lays down rules on the recognition of producer organisations and inter-branch organisations. The regulation also lays down rules on the internal functioning of producer organisations and inter-branch organisations. The regulation also lays down rules on the extension of the rules of producer organisations and inter-branch organisations. The regulation also lays down rules on the format and procedure of the notification by EU countries of rules binding on all producers or operators. The regulation also lays down rules on the format and procedure of the notification by EU countries of rules binding on all producers or operators. The regulation also lays down rules on the format and procedure of the notification by EU countries of rules binding on all producers or operators. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2014. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products (European Commission). KEY TERMS Common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products: a group of producers or operators that aim to promote the sustainable fishing activities of their members in full compliance with the conservation policy, as laid down in Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 and in environmental law, while respecting social policy and, where the EU country concerned so provides, participating in the management of marine biological resources. Cohesion Fund Cohesion Fund SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1300/2013 on the Cohesion Fund and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1084/2006 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Cohesion Fund (CF), which provides financial support to projects in the fields of environment and trans-European networks in the area of transport infrastructure. KEY POINTS The CF supports: investment in the environment, including areas related to sustainable development and energy which present environmental benefits; TEN-T, in compliance with the guidelines adopted by Regulation (EU) No 1315/2013; technical assistance. The CF does not support: the decommissioning or the construction of nuclear power stations; investment to achieve the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from activities listed in Annex I to Directive 2003/87/EC; investment in housing unless related to the promotion of energy efficiency or renewable energy use; the manufacturing, processing and marketing of tobacco and tobacco products; undertakings in difficulty, as defined under Union State aid rules; investment in airport infrastructure unless related to environmental protection or accompanied by investment necessary to mitigate or reduce its negative environmental impact. The CF supports: the shift towards a low-carbon economy in all sectors by: promoting the production and distribution of energy derived from renewable sources; promoting energy efficiency and renewable energy use in enterprises; supporting energy efficiency, smart energy management and renewable energy use in public infrastructure, including in public buildings, and in the housing sector; developing and implementing smart distribution systems that operate at low and medium voltage levels; promoting low-carbon strategies for all types of territories, in particular for urban areas, including the promotion of sustainable multimodal urban mobility and mitigation-relevant adaptation measures; the use of high-efficiency co-generation of heat and power based on useful heat demand; climate change adaptation, risk prevention and management; protecting and protecting the environment and promoting resource efficiency by: investing in the waste sector to meet the requirements of the Union's environmental acquis and to address needs, identified by the Member States, for investment that goes beyond those requirements; investing in the water sector to meet the requirements of the Union's environmental acquis and to address needs, identified by the Member States, for investment that goes beyond those requirements; protecting and restoring biodiversity and soil and promoting ecosystem services, including through Natura 2000, and green infrastructure; taking action to improve the urban environment, revitalise cities, regenerate and decontaminate brownfield sites (including conversion areas), reduce air pollution and promote noise-reduction measures; promoting sustainable transport and removing bottlenecks in key network infrastructures by: supporting a multimodal Single European Transport Area by investing in the TEN-T; developing and improving environmentally-friendly (including low-noise and low-carbon transport systems, including inland waterways and maritime transport, ports, multimodal links and airport infrastructure) and developing and rehabilitating comprehensive, high quality and interoperable railway systems; enhancing institutional capacity of public authorities and stakeholders and efficient public administration through actions to strengthen the institutional capacity and the efficiency of public administrations and public services related to the implementation of the Cohesion Fund. European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1299/2013 on specific provisions for the support from the European Regional Development Fund to the European territorial cooperation goal WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the scope of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the specific rules for its support. The ERDF is a major tool for redressing the main regional imbalances in the EU. It is a key tool for redressing the main regional imbalances in the EU. KEY POINTS The ERDF supports the following: cross-border cooperation between adjacent regions to promote integrated regional development between neighbouring land and maritime border regions in two or more EU countries or between neighbouring border regions in at least one EU country and one third country on external borders of the EU other than those covered by programmes under the external financial instruments of the EU; transnational cooperation over larger transnational territories, involving national, regional and local partners and also covering maritime cross-border cooperation in cases not covered by cross-border cooperation, with a view to achieving a higher degree of territorial integration of those territories; interregional cooperation to reinforce the effectiveness of cohesion policy by promoting: exchange of experience focusing on thematic objectives among partners throughout the EU, including in relation to the development of regions referred to in Article 174 TFEU on the identification and dissemination of good practices with a view to their transfer principally to operational programmes under the Investment for growth and jobs goal but also, where relevant, to cooperation programmes; exchange of experience concerning the identification, transfer and dissemination of good practices in relation to sustainable urban development, including urban-rural linkages; exchange of experience concerning the identification, transfer and dissemination of good practices and innovative approaches in relation to the implementation of cooperation programmes and actions as well as to the use of EGTCs; analysis of development trends in relation to the aims of territorial cohesion, including territorial aspects of economic and social cohesion, and harmonious development of Union territory through studies, data collection and other measures. Guidelines for trans-European energy infrastructure Guidelines for trans-European energy infrastructure SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 347/2013 on guidelines for trans-European energy infrastructure WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down guidelines for the timely development and interoperability of trans-European energy infrastructure (TEN-E)*. It aims to ensure the functioning of the internal energy market and security of supply in the EU, to promote energy efficiency and energy saving and the development of new and renewable forms of energy, and to promote the interconnection of energy networks. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes twelve regional groups (‘groups’) to propose and review projects of common interest. Each group adopts its own rules of procedure, taking into account the contribution of each project to implementing the energy infrastructure priority corridors and areas. The group’s decision-making powers are restricted to EU countries and the Commission. The group’s list is drawn up according to the contribution of each project to implementing the energy infrastructure priority corridors and areas and according to their fulfilment of the criteria set out in the regulation. Summary 160:
Online dispute resolution (ODR) Online dispute resolution (ODR) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 524/2013 on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes and amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Directive 2009/22/EC (Regulation on consumer ODR) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to create an online dispute resolution (ODR) platform to help consumers and traders resolve disputes arising from online sales and service contracts. It aims to improve the quality of online transactions and to boost consumer confidence in the digital dimension of the EU’s internal market. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to the out-of-court resolution of disputes concerning contractual obligations stemming from online sales or service contracts between a consumer resident in the EU and a trader established in the EU through the intervention of an ADR entity listed in accordance with Article 20(2) of Directive 2013/11/EU and which involves the use of the ODR platform. The regulation establishes an ODR platform (ODR platform) which enables consumers and traders to submit complaints to an ADR entity. The platform provides an electronic complaint form which can be filled in by the complainant party, informs the respondent party about the complaint, identify the competent ADR entity or entities and transmit the complaint to the ADR entity, which the parties have agreed to use, in accordance with Article 9 of the regulation. The platform also provides an electronic case management tool free of charge, which enables the parties and the ADR entity to conduct the dispute resolution procedure online through the ODR platform. The platform also provides an electronic form by means of which ADR entities shall transmit the information referred to in point (c) of Article 10 of the regulation. The platform also provides an online guide about how to submit complaints through the ODR platform. The regulation establishes a network of ODR contact points which provide support to the resolution of disputes relating to complaints submitted through the ODR platform. The ODR contact points provide support to the resolution of disputes relating to complaints submitted through the ODR platform by fulfilling the following functions: if requested, facilitating communication between the parties and the competent ADR entity, which may include, in particular: assisting with the submission of the complaint and, where appropriate, relevant documentation; providing the parties and ADR entities with general information on consumer rights in relation to sales and service contracts which apply in the EU of the ODR contact point which hosts the ODR advisor concerned; providing information on the functioning of the ODR platform; providing the parties with explanations on the procedural rules applied by the ADR entities identified; informing the complainant party of other means of redress when a dispute cannot be resolved through the ODR platform. The regulation also establishes a network of ODR contact points which enable cooperation between contact points and contribute to the performance of the functions listed in the regulation. The regulation also establishes a database of information on ADR entities and their updates. The regulation also establishes a committee to assist the Commission in implementing the regulation. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 9 January 2016. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Online dispute resolution (European Commission). KEY TERMS Alternative dispute resolution (ADR): a procedure for the out-of-court resolution of disputes. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) No 524/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2013 on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes and amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Directive 2009/22/EC (Regulation on consumer ODR) (OJ L 165, 18.6.2013, pp. 1–17) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) No 524/2013 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 202/2014 of 9 January 2014 on the operation of the ODR platform and amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Directive 2009/22/EC It aims to streamline and simplify the rules for direct payments to farmers under the common agricultural policy (CAP). It repeals and replaces Regulation (EC) No 73/2009 and its subsequent amendments. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the rules for direct payments to farmers under the following support schemes: basic payment for farmers; transitional simplified scheme; single area payment scheme; voluntary transitional national aid for farmers; redistributive payment; payment for farmers observing agricultural practices beneficial for the climate and the environment; payment for young farmers commencing their agricultural activity; voluntary coupled support scheme; crop-specific payment for cotton; voluntary simplified scheme for small farmers; a framework within which Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania may complement direct payments. Carriage of goods by road: statistical returns Carriage of goods by road: statistical returns SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 70/2012 on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to compile statistical data on the carriage of goods by road by means of goods road transport vehicles registered in the EU. It does not apply to: goods road transport vehicles whose authorised weight or dimensions exceed the limits normally permitted in the EU countries concerned; agricultural vehicles, military vehicles and vehicles belonging to central or local public administrations, with the exception of goods road transport vehicles belonging to public undertakings, and in particular railway undertakings. KEY POINTS Each EU country must compile statistics on the carriage of goods by road by means of goods road transport vehicles registered in that country, and on the journeys made by such vehicles. This regulation does not apply to: goods road transport vehicles whose authorised weight or dimensions exceed the limits normally permitted in the EU countries concerned; agricultural vehicles, military vehicles and vehicles belonging to central or local public administrations, with the exception of goods road transport vehicles belonging to public undertakings, and in particular railway undertakings. The regulation does not apply to Malta, so long as the number of Maltese-registered goods road transport vehicles licensed to engage in the international carriage of goods by road does not exceed 400 vehicles. Service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters Service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 on the service in the Member States of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve and speed up the transmission and service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters between the Member States. It does not extend in particular to revenue, customs or administrative matters or to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). KEY POINTS The regulation applies to civil and commercial matters where a judicial or extrajudicial document has to be transmitted from one Member State to another for service there. It does not extend in particular to revenue, customs or administrative matters or to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). The regulation does not apply where the address of the person to be served with the document is not known. The regulation does not apply to service of a document on the party’s authorised representative in the Member State where the proceedings are taking place regardless of the place of residence of that party. The regulation does not apply to service of a document on the party’s authorised representative in the Member State where the proceedings are taking place regardless of the place of residence of that party. The regulation does not apply to service of a document on the party’s authorised representative in the Member State where the proceedings are taking place regardless of the place of residence of that party. The regulation does not apply to service of a document on the party’s authorised representative in the Member State where the proceedings are taking place regardless of the place of residence of that party. The regulation does not apply to service of a document on the party’s authorised representative in the Member State where the proceedings are taking place regardless of the place of residence of that party. The regulation does not apply to service of a document on the party’s authorised representative in the Member State where the proceedings are taking place regardless of the place of residence of that party. The regulation does not apply to service of a document on the party’s authorised representative in the Member State where the proceedings are taking place regardless of the place of residence of that party. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 13 November 2008. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters (European Commission). Type approval of motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles Type approval of motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 on type approval of motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down common technical requirements for the type approval of motor vehicles (vehicles) and replacement parts, such as replacement pollution control devices, with regard to their emissions. It also lays down rules for in-service conformity, durability of pollution control devices, on-board diagnostic (OBD) systems, measurement of fuel consumption and accessibility of vehicle repair and maintenance information. KEY POINTS Manufacturers must demonstrate that all new vehicles sold, registered or put into service in the EU are type approved in accordance with this regulation and its implementing measures. Manufacturers must also demonstrate that all new replacement pollution control devices requiring type approval which are sold or put into service in the EU are type approved in accordance with this regulation and its implementing measures. Manufacturers must equip vehicles so that the components likely to affect emissions are designed, constructed and assembled so as to enable the vehicle, in normal use, to comply with this regulation and its implementing measures. Manufacturers must provide unrestricted and standardised access to vehicle repair and maintenance information to independent operators through websites using a standardised format in a readily accessible and prompt manner, and in a manner which is non-discriminatory compared to the provision given or access granted to authorised dealers and repairers. Manufacturers must make subsequent amendments and supplements to vehicle repair and maintenance information available on its websites at the same time they are made available to authorised repairers. Manufacturers may charge reasonable and proportionate fees for access to vehicle repair and maintenance information covered by this regulation; a fee is not reasonable or proportionate if it discourages access by failing to take into account the extent to which the independent operator uses it. Manufacturers must make subsequent amendments and supplements to vehicle repair and maintenance information available on its websites at the same time they are made available to authorised repairers. Food additives, food enzymes and food flavourings Food additives, food enzymes and food flavourings SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1331/2008 establishing a common authorisation procedure for food additives, food enzymes and food flavourings WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down a common procedure for the assessment and authorisation of food additives, food enzymes and food flavourings*, which contribute to the free movement of food within the EU and to a high level of protection of human health and to a high level of consumer protection, including the protection of consumer interests. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the procedures for updating the EU list of substances authorised to be placed on the EU market. The list is updated by the European Commission. The list is published in the Official Journal of the European Union. The procedure for updating the list may be started either on the initiative of the Commission or following an application. The Commission must seek the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). The authority must give its opinion within 9 months of receiving a valid application. The Commission must submit a draft regulation updating the EU list within 9 months of receiving a valid application. The Commission must consult the EFSA within 6 months of the date of entry into force of each sectoral food law. The Commission must consult the EFSA within 6 months of the date of entry into force of each sectoral food law. Accreditation and market surveillance Accreditation and market surveillance SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 765/2008 — requirements for accreditation and market surveillance relating to the marketing of products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the organisation and operation of accreditation and market surveillance* bodies* in the EU. It aims to ensure that products benefiting from the free movement of goods within the EU fulfil requirements providing a high level of protection of public interests such as health and safety in general, health and safety at the workplace, protection of consumers, protection of the environment and security. Passengers’ rights and obligations Passengers’ rights and obligations SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1371/2007 on rail passengers’ rights and obligations WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to safeguard the rights of rail passengers and to improve the quality and effectiveness of rail passenger services. It lays down rules on: information to be provided by railway undertakings, the conclusion of transport contracts, the issuing of tickets and the implementation of a Computerised Information and Reservation System for Rail Transport; liability of railway undertakings and their insurance obligations for passengers and their luggage; obligations of railway undertakings to passengers in cases of delay; protection of, and assistance to, disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility travelling by rail; definition and monitoring of service quality standards; management of risks to the personal security of passengers and the handling of complaints; general rules on enforcement. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Council Directive 95/18/EC of 19 June 1995 on the licensing of railway undertakings. The regulation does not apply to railway undertakings and transport services which are not licensed under Directive 95/18/EC. The regulation does not apply to railway undertakings and transport services which are not licensed under Directive 95/18/EC. Statistics on education and lifelong learning Statistics on education and lifelong learning SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 452/2008 — production and development of statistics on education and lifelong learning WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common framework for the systematic production of European statistics in the field of education and lifelong learning. It aims to ensure that the EU’s statistics are comparable to those of the EU countries. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to the production of statistics in three domains: education and training systems; statistics on the participation of adults in lifelong learning; other statistics on education and lifelong learning, such as statistics on human capital and on the social and economic benefits of education. The production of statistics in those domains shall be carried out in accordance with the Annex to the regulation. Statistical actions The regulation applies to the production of statistics in three domains: education and training systems; statistics on the participation of adults in lifelong learning; other statistics on education and lifelong learning, such as statistics on human capital and on the social and economic benefits of education. Summary 172:
Energy statistics: EU statistics Energy statistics: EU statistics SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1099/2008 on energy statistics WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common framework for the production, transmission, evaluation and dissemination of comparable energy statistics in the EU. It aims to ensure that the EU’s energy statistics are comparable, transparent, detailed and flexible. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the data sources and the transmission frequency of national statistics. The data are transmitted to Eurostat (Eurostat) by 31 January of the second year following the reported period. The data are aggregated at national level on the treatment or use of energy products, namely production, trade, stocks, transformation, consumption and structural characteristics of the energy system such as installed capacities for electricity generation or production capacities for oil products. Quality of data The regulation sets out the quality assessment dimensions for the data to be transmitted: relevance, accuracy, timeliness and punctuality, accessibility and clarity, comparability, coherence and completeness. Every 5 years, EU countries must provide the Commission (Eurostat) with a report on the quality of the data transmitted. The report must contain any relevant information concerning the implementation of the regulation. The regulation also sets out the methodology used to generate renewable energy statistics. The Commission (Eurostat) must present and disseminate the statistics generated from 2010 (reference year) onwards; reviewing and determining the methodology used at national and Community level to generate final energy consumption statistics (sources, variables, quality, costs) based on the current situation, existing studies and feasibility pilot studies, as well as cost-benefit analyses yet to be conducted, and evaluating the findings of the pilot studies and cost-benefit analyses with a view to establishing breakdown keys for final energies by sector and main energy uses and gradually integrating the resulting elements into the statistics from 2012 (reference year) onwards. Implementing measures The regulation sets out the measures necessary for implementation of the regulation, designed to amend non-essential elements of the regulation, inter alia, by supplementing it, with new non-essential elements. The regulation also sets out the measures necessary for implementation of the regulation, designed to amend non-essential elements of the regulation, inter alia, by supplementing it, with new non-essential elements. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 14 November 2008. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Energy statistics (European Commission). KEY TERMS Energy products: combustible fuels, heat, renewable energy, electricity, or any other form of energy. Aggregates: data aggregated at national level on the treatment or use of energy products, namely production, trade, stocks, transformation, consumption and structural characteristics of the energy system such as installed capacities for electricity generation or production capacities for oil products. Quality of data: the following aspects of statistical quality: relevance, accuracy, timeliness and punctuality, accessibility and clarity, comparability, coherence and completeness. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EC) No 1099/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 October 2008 on energy statistics (OJ L 304, 14.11.2008, pp. 1–13). Successive amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1099/2008 have been incorporated into the original document. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Rights of passengers in bus and coach transport Rights of passengers in bus and coach transport SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 181/2011 concerning the rights of passengers in bus and coach transport WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that passengers in bus and coach transport have the same rights as other citizens when using the transport service. It establishes rules for non-discrimination between passengers with regard to transport conditions offered by carriers, rights of passengers in the event of accidents arising out of the use of the bus or coach resulting in death or personal injury or loss of or damage to luggage, non-discrimination and mandatory assistance for disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility, rights of passengers in cases of cancellation or delay, minimum information to be provided to passengers, handling of complaints, general rules on enforcement. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to passengers travelling with regular services for non-specified categories of passengers where the boarding or the alighting point of the passengers is situated in the territory of a Member State and where the scheduled distance of the service is 250 km or more. The regulation does not apply to passengers travelling with occasional services where the initial boarding point or the final alighting point of the passenger is situated in the territory of a Member State. EU scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries EU scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 — laying down a scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the general rules and conditions for the application by the EU of the scheme adopted by the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC). KEY POINTS EU countries must send to the European Commission, in a computer-readable form, a list of all vessels flying their flag and registered in the EU which are authorised to fish in the Regulatory Area, in particular the vessels authorised to fish directly for one or more regulated resources together with any amendments to the list. The list must be sent no later than 15 December each year or no later than 5 days before the vessel enters the Regulatory Area. The masters of EU fishing vessels must record, either in a bound paginated fishing logbook or by electronic means, the following: each entry into and exit from the Regulatory Area; on a daily basis and/or for each haul the estimated cumulative catches retained on board since the last entry into the Regulatory Area; on a daily basis and/or for each haul the amount of fish discarded; immediately after each communication pursuant to Article 9, the date and time, according to Universal Coordinated Time (UTC), of transmission of a report and, in the case of radio transmission, the name of the radio station through which the report was transmitted; the fishing depth, where appropriate. The masters of EU fishing vessels must record, either in a bound paginated fishing logbook or by electronic means, the following: each entry into and exit from the Regulatory Area; on a daily basis and/or for each haul the estimated cumulative catches retained on board since the last entry into the Regulatory Area; on a daily basis and/or for each haul the amount of fish discarded; immediately after each communication pursuant to Article 9, the date and time, according to Universal Coordinated Time (UTC), of transmission of a report and, in the case of radio transmission, the name of the radio station through which the report was transmitted; the fishing depth, where appropriate. The masters of EU fishing vessels must communicate catch reports by electronic means to their Fisheries Monitoring Centre, as defined in Article 4 of Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009. The data contained in these reports must be accessible to the Commission on request. EU Ecolabel: voluntary labelling scheme EU Ecolabel: voluntary labelling scheme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 66/2010 on the EU Ecolabel WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules for the establishment and application of the voluntary EU Ecolabel (EU Ecolabel) scheme. It aims to promote products with a reduced environmental impact during their entire life cycle and to provide consumers with accurate, non-deceptive, science-based information on the environmental impact of products. KEY POINTS The EU Ecolabel is a voluntary labelling scheme designed to promote products with a reduced environmental impact during their entire life cycle and to provide consumers with accurate, non-deceptive, science-based information on the environmental impact of products. It is part of the sustainable consumption and production policy of the EU, which aims at reducing the negative impact of consumption and production on the environment, health, climate and natural resources. The EU Ecolabel is based on the environmental performance of products, taking into account the latest strategic objectives of the EU in the field of the environment. Summary 177:
Supplementary protection certificate for medicinal products Supplementary protection certificate for medicinal products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 469/2009 — supplementary protection certificate for medicinal products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It codifies Regulation (EEC) No 1768/92 concerning the creation of a supplementary protection certificate for medicinal products. It aims to provide adequate protection to encourage pharmaceutical research. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to any product protected by a patent in the territory of an EU country and subject, prior to being placed on the market as a medicinal product, to an administrative authorisation procedure as laid down in Directive 2001/83/EC or Directive 2001/82/EC, as appropriate. The application for a certificate must contain: a request for the grant of a certificate, stating in particular: the name and address of the applicant; if he has appointed a representative, the name and address of the representative; the number of the basic patent and the title of the invention; the number and date of the first authorisation to place the product on the market, as appropriate; a copy of the authorisation to place the product on the market, as indicated in the notification; if the authorisation is not the first authorisation for placing the product on the market as a medicinal product in the EU, information regarding the identity of the product thus authorised and the legal provision under which the authorisation procedure took place, together with a copy of the notice publishing the authorisation in the appropriate official publication; where necessary, in addition to the copy of the authorisation to place the product on the market, information regarding the identity of the product thus authorised and the legal provision under which the authorisation procedure took place, together with a copy of the notice publishing the authorisation in the appropriate official publication; where necessary, in addition to the copy of the authorisation to place the product on the market, information regarding the identity of the product thus authorised and the legal provision under which the authorisation procedure took place, together with a copy of the notice publishing the authorisation in the appropriate official publication; where necessary, in addition to the copy of the authorisation to place the product on the market, information regarding the identity of the product thus authorised and the legal provision under which the authorisation procedure took place, together with a copy of the notice publishing the authorisation in the appropriate official publication; Summary 178:
Jurisdiction and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters Jurisdiction and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters SUMMARY OF: Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters Decision 2009/17/EC — conclusion of the Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE CONVENTION AND OF THE DECISION? The convention aims to strengthen legal protection of persons in the EU by establishing the international jurisdiction of the courts, to facilitate recognition and to introduce an expeditious procedure for securing the enforcement of judgments, authentic instruments and court settlements. KEY POINTS The convention applies to civil and commercial matters whatever the nature of the court or tribunal. It does not extend, in particular, to revenue, customs or administrative matters. The convention does not apply to: the status or legal capacity of natural persons, rights in property arising out of a matrimonial relationship, wills and succession; bankruptcy, proceedings relating to the winding-up of insolvent companies or other legal persons, judicial arrangements, compositions and analogous proceedings; social security; arbitration. The convention does not apply to: the status or legal capacity of natural persons, rights in property arising out of a matrimonial relationship, wills and succession; bankruptcy, proceedings relating to the winding-up of insolvent companies or other legal persons, judicial arrangements, compositions and analogous proceedings; social security; arbitration.
